Award.AwardTitle: Sources and Growth of Initial Condition Errors in Convection-resolving Forecasts in the Mesoscale Predictability Experiment (MPEX)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research focuses on understanding how errors associated with particular features prior to convective initiation can influence forecasts of convection over the Great Plains region of the United States within the Mesoscale Predictability Experiment (MPEX). In particular, this study will evaluate the hypothesis that errors associated with upper-level synoptic features, midtropospheric moisture, midtropospheric lapse rate, and boundary layer moisture and shear at 18-24 h and 1 h prior to convective initiation are responsible for the lack of predictability in convection forecasts. These hypotheses will be validated by running a series of experiments whereby different sets of observations are assimilated within the most sensitive regions and compared to the control where these observations are withheld. In addition, the ensemble-based sensitivity technique will be applied to 3 km Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model ensemble forecasts that use initial conditions from a cycling ensemble Kalman filter. The sensitivities that are obtained from this method will also be evaluated by producing perturbed initial conditions that are consistent with adjusting a feature of interest (i.e., midtropospheric moisture) and comparing the resulting forecasts against the control where no perturbation is applied. The results from several cases will be compared to each other to evaluate whether convective forecasts are consistently sensitive to particular fields and features and the degree to which each case is characterized by unique sensitivities.

Intellectual Merit:
This project will enhance our understanding of the dynamical processes that limit the predictability of convective systems over a range of cases using an ensemble of convection-resolving forecasts. Moreover, this study will also demonstrate whether sensitivity analysis, which has typically been applied to phenomena characterized by linear error growth over longer time scales can be applicable to convection, which is characterized by non-linear dynamics and error growth over short time scales.

Broader Impacts:
The results from this study could provide guidance of where to take observations during future convective events that could be assimilated into numerical prediction models, which will hopefully produce better forecasts, greater lead time for warnings, and reduced loss of life. The results will be communicated with operational forecasters and others in the research communities to design better ways to observe the atmosphere and evaluate numerical models. Moreover, this study will also allow for the training of a graduate student in predictability, convective dynamics and data assimilation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project is to quantify how uncertainties in estimates of the atmospheric wind, temperature, and moisture fields at earlier times impact numerical weather prediction model forecasts of severe thunderstorms later in the afternoon.  In theory, incorporating observations into models in regions where the atmospheric field uncertainties have the largest impact on the thunderstorm forecast (i.e., most sensitive regions) could improve the forecasts.  This sensitivity is quantified by applying ensemble-based sensitivity analysis to large sets of computer model forecasts, which differ by their initial representation of the atmosphere.  This project was a component of the Mesoscale Predictability Experiment from May-June 2013, which included using sensitivity analysis to direct the NCAR Gulfstream-V aircraft to take observations of the atmosphere that could improve subsequent severe thunderstorm forecasts.  Our research focused on a series of cases from this period, which were characterized by different degrees of societal impact (some high impact cases, some non-severe cases).  Moreover, some of the cases were quite predictable, while other cases were characterized by a greater variety of potential outcomes in the thunderstorm evolution.  In turn, the project expanded our understanding of the physical processes that limit the predictability of severe thunderstorms.

The results from this work suggest that a wide variety of features can impact forecasts of severe thunderstorms in the Central United States.  For those cases where the meteorological features in the atmosphere tend to focus the severe thunderstorms in particular locations (hereafter “strong forcing”), the forecasts tended to be most sensitive to the location of wind anomalies around 4 km above the ground.  In the two cases we studied, these anomalies would often pass by the region of interest during the morning prior to thunderstorm initiation, thereby changing the position of near-surface moisture boundaries that became of the focus point of the thunderstorms.  By contrast, the forecasts exhibited little sensitivity to the main meteorological features that most severe weather forecasters believe are important to thunderstorm initiation for these cases.  These results suggest that improved observational coverage within these vertical levels may improve severe thunderstorm forecasts during events that are generally well forecast.

In addition, a second class of case was studied, denoted “weakly forced”, which are cases with a lack of features that would otherwise focus convection in Texas along the dryline.  For these cases, our results indicate that the severe thunderstorm forecasts are most sensitive to the position of these near-surface moisture boundaries as well; however, the position of these boundaries is impacted by small errors in the wind and moisture field along the boundary to the south during earlier times.  In one case, the model’s forecast of overnight thunderstorms 18 h earlier impacted the position of the boundary during the next afternoon.  Moreover, we also developed a method to determine which thunderstorm forecasts would be more accurate by seeing how the model was performing against observations with regions where the model’s thunderstorm forecast was “sensitive” to the atmosphere.  Forecasts that verified closer to observations within the sensitive region during the morning had better forecasts of thunderstorm location and coverage later in the afternoon.

Finally, we applied these techniques to a case of severe weather in Nebraska and South Dakota, which is not as favorable location for this type of event.  Similar to the Southern Plains, the forecasts were most sensitive to the position of moisture boundaries, whose position were strongly tied to uncertainty associated with features higher in the atmosphere.

The broader impacts of this project are the development of techniques that could be used to adaptively determine locations to take observations during severe thunderstorm events.  In turn, these observations could lead to improved computer model forecasts of these events, though not all cases showed improvement.  In particular, these results suggest that additional observations that sample moisture boundaries could lead to improved thunderstorm forecasts, yielding decreased vulnerabilities to life and property.  A portion of the funding for this project was used to train a graduate student in numerical weather prediction, sensitivity analysis, and thunderstorm motions.  During this project, he earned the equivalent of an MS degree and is continuing onto a PhD.
